metadata.description: Price elasticity parameters for seasonal retail promotions across channels
metadata.estimation_method: Synthetic calibration using prestige vs mass promo benchmarks and channel-specific discount sensitivity
metadata.data_source: Composite benchmarks from prestige retail, mass retail, and marketplace promo behavior (2022-2025)
metadata.real_world_validation: Mass channels show higher elasticity than prestige channels; repeat customers are less price-sensitive
benchmark_sources: Beauty retail promo benchmarks (prestige vs mass channel elasticity ranges)
Marketplace discount response studies (category-level demand shifts)
Seasonal sell-through guidance from beauty and personal care
metadata.validation: Parameters tuned to align with seasonal retail promo behavior while preserving model stability.

ad_supported.interpretation: Elastic demand - 1% price increase leads to 2.1% decrease in units

new_0_3mo.description: New customers (0-3 months) - highly price sensitive

tenured_3_12mo.description: Repeat customers (3-12 months) - moderately price sensitive

tenured_12plus.description: Loyal customers (12+ months) - less price sensitive

ad_free.interpretation: Moderately elastic demand - 1% price increase leads to 1.5% decrease in units

new_0_3mo.description: New customers (0-3 months) - moderately price sensitive

tenured_3_12mo.description: Repeat customers (3-12 months) - standard price sensitivity

tenured_12plus.description: Prestige loyalists (12+ months) - less price sensitive

short_term_0_3mo.description: Short-term elasticity higher due to promo sensitivity

long_term_12plus.description: Long-term elasticity lower as loyalty builds

external_factor_adjustments.description: How external factors modify price elasticity

high_inflation.description: During high inflation, shoppers are more price sensitive

high_unemployment.description: During high unemployment, price sensitivity increases

low_consumer_sentiment.description: During low sentiment, price sensitivity increases

competitor_price_increase.description: When competitors raise prices, elasticity decreases

competitor_price_decrease.description: When competitors lower prices, elasticity increases

viral_spike.description: Viral social moment reduces price sensitivity

willingness_to_pay.description: Distribution of willingness to pay (WTP) by channel group

ad_supported.interpretation: 50% of mass-channel shoppers willing to pay $24 or more

ad_free.interpretation: 50% of prestige-channel shoppers willing to pay $36.50 or more

repeat_loss_elasticity.description: How repeat-loss rate changes with price changes

ad_supported.interpretation: 1% price increase leads to 0.85% increase in repeat loss

ad_free.interpretation: 1% price increase leads to 0.65% increase in repeat loss

acquisition_elasticity.description: How new customer acquisition changes with price changes

ad_supported.interpretation: 1% price increase leads to 1.7% decrease in new customers

ad_free.interpretation: 1% price increase leads to 1.4% decrease in new customers

notes.estimation_approach: Retail promo benchmarks and synthetic calibration
notes.methodology: Elasticity values derived from retail promo response patterns and category benchmarks (2022-2025).
notes.benchmark_validation: Discount depth and price changes calibrated to typical beauty retail response curves.
assumptions: Cross-price elasticity assumes competitors maintain current pricing
Segment-level elasticity assumes homogeneity within segments
Time horizon adjustments based on observed retail behavior
notes.confidence: High confidence (0.88) - values derived from market observations.
notes.use_case: Suitable for POC simulation, scenario modeling, and pricing strategy exploration.
notes.update_frequency: Review annually or after major channel shifts.
